content: {{knowledge objective |Identifiant=OIC-049-21-B |Item_parent=Normal and pathological puberty |Item_parent_short=Normal and pathological puberty |Rank=B |Title=Photographs: premature thelarche |Description=None |Rubric=Multimedia content |Contributors= |Order=21}} The typical ''premature thelarche'' in girls under 2 years of age most often begins in the perinatal period, with breast development progressing relatively little thereafter. If there is any doubt, a simple pelvic ultrasound showing prepubertal internal genitalia will suggest the diagnosis of isolated ''premature thelarche''. [File:Premature thelarche infant 10 months.png|left|thumb]]

question.question: In girls under 2 years of age, what is the typical onset and progression of premature thelarche?
question.option_a: It begins in the perinatal period and progresses rapidly.
question.option_b: It begins in the perinatal period and progresses relatively little thereafter.
question.option_c: It begins after the first year and progresses rapidly.
question.option_d: It begins after the first year and progresses relatively little thereafter.
